description: Borrowed from Middle French réviser, from Latin revīsere, from re- + vīsere (“examine”), frequentative of vidēre (“see”).

entries.meaning: (printing) A second proof sheet; a proof sheet taken after the first or a subsequent correction.
examples: The question is, not whether the revises of the Catalogue, which I was obliged to circulate prematurely, were faultless, but whether the alterations which I was desired to make would not render them worse.

verbs.description: revise (third-person singular simple present revises, present participle revising, simple past and past participle revised)

entries.meaning: To review, alter and amend, especially of written material.
(UK, Australia, New Zealand) To look over again (something previously written or learned), especially in preparation for an examination.
examples: I should be revising for my exam in a few days.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To look at again, to reflect on.
